posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Before this upcoming season, I’m working on making an electrical bible for our newcomers and other teams in FIRST . Is there anything that should definitely be added?

posts.name: Alex He
posts.cooked: Can you share a draft of it? I’m excited to see it

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: Most components (i.e. PDH ) have a recommended length to strip the wires too. Such a simple thing but it really increases reliability if you follow it.

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: Read the docs and the manuals for all electrical components you use, they have recommendations for everything even down to the gauge of wire to use. When you read the manual / docs the robots reliability with electrical goes way up. Last if you can easily touch the connector between two wire great, if you can, there shouldn’t be a connect either use a new wire or solder it so it can not come undone.

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked: Use CTRE Beaker to test batteries before competition

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Use a Battery Analyzer to test your batteries before competition, use the Beak to test it at competition.   It gives a really good picture of capacity, especially if your bot is very power hungry.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
There are plenty of comments in threads here on CD about wiring. There are also several old FRC electrical bibles. Arguably the worst offences on my team have been:

Wrong size wire (painful rewiring)

Use of CCA (copper clad aluminum; painful rewiring)

Dressing wire runs too tightly (failures and no slack for minor adjustments)

Anchoring wires too close or too far from terminals. Molex, for example, has charts of where to put anchors near the terminals. The pin and sockets have to float to make a good connection. Too tight and they won’t float.

Not setting the barbs or catches in terminals. Failure to do so gives poor or essentially no connection surface as one side pushes out the other side instead of mating or detachment when in use on the robot.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
In the past, it was actually hard to find CCA wire in the sizes used for FRC , especially if you avoid solid wire – which is something you should certainly do.  These days, this is less true if you source really cheap (typically, overseas) wire though.

I’ve seen many, including inspectors, confused by tinned copper (good) vs. CCA (copper-colored, but not allowed for power wiring: R609, R622).

This past season, I was sad to see a team needlessly rewiring a robot because they had stranded tinned copper wire on their robot – including some that was built into an FRC KoP/explicitly allowed item.  They were mostly done by the time I noticed, but we did straighten things out.

If there’s any doubt, it’s good to bring documentation of the specific wire you have used.  This sometimes comes up with wire gauge also, so keeping a notebook with documentation of parts, including wire is a good practice.  In the case of wire, you can also have a sample that makes it easier to read the marking on the wire, or to look at the cut end.  Read the rules and pay attention.

link_counts.title: Cable Guide: CCA Cable - Yifang Electric Group Inc.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: If Amazon is your “go to” supplier and the purchasing person with the credit card doesn’t have the subtle specifications memorized it’s now easy to get the wrong stuff. Zip cord wire for speakers and automotive abound and often the description doesn’t even say “CCA”. This example is one of the easier ones to avoid but only if you are “in-the-know” - it does claim top-tier High-Grade. Don’t buy this!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Definitely don’t buy wire from Amazon, go to an electronics supplier (my “go to” for zip cord wire is PowerWerx).

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: We have had good luck with BNTECHGO tinned copper silicone insulated wire from Amazon.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
nuttle:

I’ve seen many, including inspectors, confused by tinned copper (good) vs. CCA (copper-colored, but not allowed for power wiring: R609, R622).

Our electrical standards doc at 2151 calls out to avoid CCA wire and describes how to differentiate tinned copper - the situation you described is a real shame and could have been addressed through RI better training.  If you know enough to look for CCA, you should know enough to differentiate the two as they appear almost totally opposite.  One with a yummy copper center and the other with a yucky aluminum core.

Bringing a sample is a good idea for sure.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Bmongar:

BNTECHGO tinned copper silicone insulated

I feel some of the “silicone” insulated wires has insulation has quite soft insulation - you can strip it with your fingernail.  I’m worried about the ease of damage getting pinched or nicked.

I think I’ve got some BNTECHGO in my stash and I seem to recall it’s one of the better ones but I’ve been pretty disappointed in others.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Our team has liked the flexibility of the silicone insulated wires.  They are softer for sure though near moving parts we are always running in split loom or nylon wrapped loom

posts.name: Zach Kerfoot
posts.cooked: We’ve ordered from Amazon for a number of years now, catch being we make sure to order the PowerWerx branded wire . Never had any issues with getting the correct wire.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I think thats the “between the lines” point Peter is underscoring. Purchasing wire from amazon can be fraught with peril. If you are purchasing a trusted product and specific brand you can have good results.

On the other hand purchasing a previously trusted brand or a new brand and a new-to-you product there are dozens of bad results for every good result and can easily cause a mix-up to a layperson or even someone who thinks they know what they are doing (an IT professional), but doesn’t pay attention to the details (CCA, or no mention of the wire type/construction, but it matches all the other specs!)

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: Arguably the number 1 battery rule is never to plug two batteries together or let the terminals short. Sure the first few sparks are pretty but what comes after those isn’t

posts.name: Alya Kurt
posts.cooked: We are also working on a similar Electrical Bible project Happy to collaborate if you are up!! Also, my suggestion would be to include a table for each electrical component, their power cables AWG measurement and which circuit breaker/on what spot on VRM should they connect. In addition details on when to use a PWM connection or for example, REV Servo Power Module would help a lot of teams. Seeing a lot of components and not knowing which ones are essential etc. can confuse beginners. Lastly, the network switch is a big issue for most teams who don’t have a brainboxes ethernet switch. For example, we were using TP-LINK TL-SF1005D and the barrel plug really made us lose connection a lot. Including a section regarding how to get rid of the barrel plug connection and replace it with soldering would save a ton of teams (a similar demonstration was also in ZebraSwitch2 ).

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
I made a cheat sheet for my team. It is not complete by any means, but they found it helpful.

The orientation of the Powerpole connectors is a real RACES/ARES standard, but the the orientation of the the Molex SL connectors is an internal standard for our team, and you may want to change it for your team. To me, having pin 1 be CAN Low makes the most sense.

The graphics in this PDF are mostly vector based, so it is easy to edit (like recoloring the wires on the Molex SL connectors) and enlarge.

FRC 3647 Electrical Cheat Sheet V3.pdf (3.0 MB)
